The BPCS Downtown Elementary completed stop 2 of their "Math Olympics" this April! That means that K-2 students have collectively solved a whopping 13,000 math problems so far over the past two months. This stop in Lagos, Nigeria, brings them one step closer to their ultimate Math Olympics destination to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. There are many other stops and many other math problems to go and students will be learning about different countries, their geographies, histories, sports, music, and arts along the way. By the end, students will have completed 1 MILLION math problems.

E DUPE (many thanks in Yoruba) to all the parents who volunteered to help us celebrate Nigeria at this month's Townhall meeting. It was delightful to explore Nigeria's beaches, cityscapes, soccer games, as well as learn about the Yoruba people and their traditions, crafts, and songs.

We will be completing 137, 600 problems for our arrival in New Delhi, India next month - or approximately 29 problems per day, per student. #motivationmonday

Last week, Mr. Cheung's high school advisory class had the chance to visit several kindergarten and 2nd grade classrooms at BPCS Downtown Elementary to model good student behavior, scholarship, and to assist students in their learning.

"My advisees are quite excited - but also partially nervous about the silly things, such as whether or not they'll know enough 2nd grade science or what to do if a student sneezes on them!" said Mr. Cheung. It goes without saying that the collaboration went spectacularly, with our elementary students thriving on the individual attention and our high school students getting a boost to their self-confidence by following elementary school lesson plans crafted by teachers.

Students collaborated across multiple subjects, including: music, Spanish, science, art, and dance. They even got to work towards a common goal in the BPCS Downtown Elementary "Math Olympics".

We couldn't be more proud of what our younger and older students are learning about themselves and about each other.

Extra special contributions to the map came from photos, ideas, artifacts that artists brought in via homework.
